creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
inscription:
Signature, Date, Inscription, Stamp

inscribed in plate at top: [HERCVLES MVLTIS BELLIS LACESSIT TROIAM]
markings: pink stamp on verso, LL: Lawrason Riggs, Lugt 1756c; black stamp on verso, LL: Robert Scholtz, Lugt 2241. Also on verso: loan number for 1941 Baltimore exhibition.
provenance: Lawrason Riggs (1861-1940), Lugt 1756c, Baltimore. Robert Scholtz (1834-1912), Lugt 224, Budapest (sale, H. G. Gutekunst, Stuttgart, May 1911).  [Kennedy Galleries, New York.] John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie; gave to MIA, 2015. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
signed: monogram in plate at lower right: [HSB]; date in plate at lower left: [1545]
text:
The legendary strongman Hercules was born to the god Zeus and a mortal named Alcmena. This union so incensed Zeus’s wife Hera that she made life almost unbearable for the hero. Her ire resulted in him undertaking a series of tasks, known as the Twelve Labors of Hercules. Sebald Beham challenged his audience’s knowledge of the classical text, engraving three actual labors and nine scenes of Hercules’ exploits before and after his labors.

After completing his tasks, Hercules heads off to do battle in Troy. Beham learned from Albrecht Dürer’s horse studies, which Beham published under his own name.
title: Hercules Fighting the Trojans, From the Labors of Hercules
